notes: A sensing device that measures a vehicle's acceleration.
Actions taken to reduce the chances of an accident occurring.
Enable a previously deactivated geofence to resume monitoring.
A report that summarizes the list of devices that are active at the time of generating the report.
When the app is actively being used for its main functions, such as tracking the driver or scanning for nearby devices.
A report that summarizes the list of vehicles that are active at the time of generating the report along with device association information. See Device Association.
A feature that allows users to add additional information or responses to the issues listed in the device's Issues Tab.
A process for entering and saving information for multiple drivers at once, using a bulk upload feature.
A process for entering and saving information for a single driver in the system.
A box where users can write detailed information about their feedback or issues.
An option to select and store a video for further processing or downloading.
The option to add an alert to a driver's coaching session for further review.
Technology that helps drivers avoid accidents and improve safety while driving.
Alerts that provide recommendations for safer driving but do not indicate a violation.
An alert triggered when a driver doesnâ€šÃ„Ã´t maintain a safe distance after changing lanes.
Real-time driving events captured by the Driverâ€šÃ„Â¢i device that provide visibility to driving behavior and incidents that may need quick action.
Displays the alert description (name, severity, caution), awarded DriverStars, vehicle speed, posted speed limit, and relative speed (REL) in a fleet management system.
A button on the Driverâ€šÃ„Â¢i device used to trigger a Driver Initiated Alert.
A visual representation of a driver's alert within the system, showing whether an alert has been fully or partially viewed by the driver..
The specific reason or situation that triggered an alert.
A report that summarizes the Alerts that are converted to DriverStars or Neutral Events. See DriverStars and Neutral Events.
The total number of notifications or warnings generated due to events or issues.
The length of time the alert was active, depending on specific filters applied to the alert.
Comments or decisions made by safety managers after reviewing driver alerts.
A tool in fleet management systems that enables filtering alerts based on driver star ratings.
The number of times a specific alert (e.g., speeding or distracted driving) occurs over a set period.
A tool to customize alert settings based on specific geographic areas.
Categories of alerts grouped based on the type of safety issues, helping to identify recurring safety problems
Alert icons are small symbols used to represent specific types of driving-related alerts visually.
A unique identifier assigned to each alert for easy tracking and reference.
A list of specific alerts that are eligible for review and coaching, configured by the manager.
A visual representation showing alerts triggered by drivers over a selected period.
A section showing all the alerts included in a coaching session.
A short video preview related to the alert, allowing the driver or manager to see an example of the event that triggered the alert.
The process of reviewing an alert to determine its validity. This process can be initiated by either the driver or safety manager.
A summary of safety risks associated with a fleet or driver based on alert data.
A tool within the system that allows users to filter and locate specific types of alerts based on criteria such as behavior, severity, or frequency.
A classification that indicates how serious or risky an alert is, guiding the priority of coaching required.
A more specific classification within an alert type, providing further details (e.g., "Severe" or "Minor").
The Date and Time when the Alert was detected.
The category of an alert, such as speeding or distracted driving.
A recording showing instances of alerts like hard acceleration, with a graph for analysis.
A process that determines which videos are shown, giving priority to high-severity alerts over lower-severity ones.
A window in the player that shows driver details, video options, and other alert-related actions.
A tool to play recorded videos from various cameras, primarily used to review driving footage for training, evidence, and security purposes.
A system used to manage the display of alerts efficiently on the portal, ensuring only necessary information is shown.
translation_nl: Waarschuwingsalgoritme voor het afsnijden van video's

notes: displays all the Alert Videos that have multiple camera views (Inward, Outward, Left, and Right).
Notifications triggered just before a collision to provide additional context.
A set of rules or steps a computer follows to detect unsafe driving behaviors.
A button that opens a list of all alerts generated by the driver.
â€šÃ„ÃºAll Alertsâ€šÃ„Ã¹ Report displays the complete list of Alerts for the Fleet for the selected duration and report configuration.
A tab comparing the performance scores of all drivers to identify trends or outliers.
The height of an object or point above a given reference, usually above sea level.
The amount of driving time required to calculate GreenZone Scores.
Notes or markers added to videos to highlight specific driving events or objects detected by the system, like vehicles or road signs.
Alerts shown within a mobile or desktop application.
A button to confirm and apply your selected filters to the events list.
Month
A page where managers can assign drivers to trips or alerts that lack driver information.
The process of linking a driver to unassigned drive times.
Status shown when the driver assignment is being updated and has not yet taken effect.
A feature that lets users upload pictures to help explain their feedback.
Maintaining focus while driving consistently over time.
Specific parameters like Driver Score or Green Minutes %, used for generating custom reports.
A feature that lets you record sounds inside the vehicle to provide extra details about driving events.
Settings that enable or disable audio recording for alert videos.
A process to verify a user's identity using a username and password.
Information that is automatically filled in by the system based on the selected alert or vehicle.
A process where certain aspects of coaching are automated, such as sending alerts to drivers without requiring manual intervention.
A session automatically created for a driver based on pre-configured alerts or recommendations.
Training or feedback sessions that are automatically created based on the driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s performance, helping them improve their driving.
A status indicating that a video must be specifically requested before it can be viewed.
The average amount of time it takes for a driver to reach the vehicle ahead, calculated over a set period.
A higher GreenZone score indicates safe driving behavior.
Generated when the vehicle goes in reverse at a high speed for more than the pre-defined duration.
A warning given when a vehicle reverses too fast for too long.
A warning when the tracking device isnâ€šÃ„Ã´t securely attached to the vehicle.
A physical gate or arm used to block traffic at a railroad crossing when a train is passing.
A single type of alert that is not combined with any other alert.
Alerts generated from fundamental driving behavior issues, such as speeding or distracted driving.
The reference level on the alert video graph, used to compare spikes during incidents like hard braking.
The central line on the yellow trace graph; deviations above or below indicate left or right turns.
The condition or performance level of the phone's battery, which can affect its ability to hold charge or its overall efficiency.

Wireless transmitters that use low-energy Bluetooth technology to send signals to other smart devices that are nearby, such as the Driverâ€šÃ„Â¢i Camera. Beacons are used to associate a Driver to the vehicle during their drive time.
The direction or path along which something moves or along which it is located.
New alert that is under evaluation and can be used for coaching but does not impact GreenZone score.
Areas around a vehicle that the driver cannot see using mirrors.
A wireless technology that allows the app to communicate with nearby devices, such as tracking the driver.
A setting that allows the app to connect to devices using Bluetooth.
The option to save an event for later reference or discussion.
Mark an event as important to easily find and view it later.
Alerts marked as important for easy reference during coaching.
Colored boxes (red, yellow, or green) seen in video annotations, showing the following distance.
How hard the brakes are applied, measured in G-force.
Alerts shown directly on your web browser.
A feature that allows users to update details for multiple drivers at once, rather than editing each driver individually.
Adding multiple geofences at once using a pre-filled CSV file.

Camera configuration settings that are applicable at the Fleet level. Fleets can enable or disable the left, right, and inward cameras on the D-410 device and inward camera on the D-210 device. Additional cameras can be configured if the user has Driverâ€šÃ„Â¢i Hubx.
Different perspectives (e.g., outward, inward, left, right) available for reviewing recorded videos.
Problems in connecting devices to a vehicle's CAN bus, preventing data reading. Some issues may resolve automatically, while others require customer action or Netradyne support.
A system ensuring proper connection between vehicle components and the Driver.i device to meet compliance requirements.
Language
A detailed summary of driver alerts displayed in an organized card format.
Visual sections on the dashboard summarizing specific information and providing access to detailed data.
A large truck designed to transport liquids or gases, such as gasoline, which can carry hazardous materials.
A section where selected videos are stored temporarily before completing a request.
The reason behind an alert being triggered, such as a violation or unsafe behavior.
A progress milestone in a streak that tracks safe driving for a set amount of time.
Arranged in the sequence of time, showing events from the earliest to the latest.
A geofence defined by a central point with a radius to form a circular boundary.
The city where the geofence is located.
Heavy-duty vehicles classified based on their weight
Events that can put the driver or the vehicle at risk while driving. Also called Alerts, these events impact the GreenZone Score negatively.
Indicates that the driver has reviewed the alert and completed the coaching process.
Settings that allow safety managers to customize how coaching sessions are structured, such as choosing which alerts to share and when they are shared.
The person responsible for reviewing, assigning, and conducting coaching sessions with drivers.
Identifying which drivers require guidance based on their alerts or driving behavior.
Criteria used to decide if a driver needs coaching, like score thresholds.
A review of the Coaching Session by the Manager that marks the session complete.
The settings used by Safety Managers to set up coaching sessions. This can include adding specific alerts from the Events screen or selecting other options to tailor the session.
Written records made during or after a coaching session that summarize key points, such as alerts, driver responses, and improvement plans.
A training session for drivers, which includes alert examples and driving statistics. Coaching Sessions are focused on helping Fleets improve driver performance.
The current progress of coaching related to an alert, indicating whether the driver has reviewed it, completed it, or requires further coaching.
The process of analyzing and handling incidents where vehicles are involved in crashes, even minor ones.
Generated when the driver is 2.6 seconds ahead of an impending collision with any stopped, slowly moving, or braking vehicle in front.
A text box where users can write their suggestions or explain their feedback.
A section where managers can add notes related to an alert, visible to drivers in the Driverâ€šÃ„Â¢i App.
Large vehicles used for business purposes, such as transporting goods or passengers.
Feature that helps compare selected Driver Group(s) in a Fleet.
Checking the difference between the current and previous scores for a driver or fleet.
Comparing the number of completed Coaching Sessions helps Fleet managers understand their training effectiveness and identify areas where additional coaching may be needed for drivers in the Groups.
A coaching session that has been fully reviewed and marked as completed by the driver.
A section showing disputes that have been reviewed and resolved.
The percentage of times a driver or fleet follows the rules compared to all attempts.
Comparison between the Fleet and the drivers' performance based on Alert Type Compliance. This can be accessed from the GreenZone Statistics page in IDMS Portal.
A combination of two Base Alerts that occurred closely together in the same minute.
Settings that can be adjusted to customize the alerts and cameras for a fleet.
configuration page enables the customers to perform fleet level configuration for certain features of the Netradyne Portal.
Busy roads with heavy traffic, making navigation and parking challenging.
The ability to analyze what happened before and after an alert to understand the situation better.
The ability to steer and maneuver the vehicle safely while driving.
Steps that can be taken based on dashboard insights to address identified operational or administrative issues.
The time a driver has to adjust their behavior after hearing an alert before a dashboard notification is issued.
A section where users can request additional video footage by providing necessary details.
An option in the portal to generate a new driver report based on selected criteria.
Indicates that a driver has been successfully added to the system, but may not yet be fully operational or active.
A DriverStar awarded when the driver reduces speed to maintain safe distance, contributing positively to the GreenZone score.
A set of information, like a username and password, used for login.
A file format that stores data in a plain text, table-like structure with values separated by commas.
A file format used to upload or manage multiple geofences at once.
A specific date range chosen by the user.
A tool to select specific weeks or months to view accurate GreenZone Scores.
A feature allowing reports to be generated for specific drivers meeting certain conditions.
Geofences created to match specific needs or requirements of a fleet.
The response of a customer regarding the return of a defective device, which can include actions like confirming return, requesting a call, or being unreachable.
People riding bicycles, who may also be crossing intersections.
Specific models of Driverâ€šÃ„Â¢i devices that detect severe drowsiness.
Time frequency
Module in the Netradyne Portal that allows the user to gain insights into the Fleet performance and operational updates.
A visual or audio notification on the dashboard, advising the driver about safety-related events.
Dashboard Alert is generated if the driver does not act upon the In-Cab Audio Alert within a pre-configured time.
A tool to choose the time frame (weekly, monthly, or custom) for viewing compliance data.
The specific time period for which data is displayed on the chart.
Time frequency
Time frequency
Temporarily disable a geofence so it no longer monitors the area.
Drivers that are no longer associated with the fleet are moved to deactivated state. Deactivated drivers can be activated at any point of time, if required.
A geofence that is turned off or no longer in use.
Monthly
The rate at which a vehicle slows down.
Difficulty in steering or managing the vehicle while reversing.
Pre-configured values applied automatically if specific details are not provided (e.g., radius of 50m).
Techniques used to anticipate and react to potential hazards on the road, aiming to reduce accidents and improve safety.
Methods and strategies aimed at preventing accidents or reducing risks, such as maintaining safe following distance or avoiding distractions.
The option to remove incorrect data entries before uploading the correct ones.
Points added to a driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s record for violations, which can lead to penalties or license suspension.
Condition of the device. Device Health can help identify devices that did not respond for more than 24 hours, devices that have issues reported, and devices to be returned (RMA devices).
A report that summarizes the health condition of the device.
Part of the Fleet Admin page providing insights into device health and facilitating proactive maintenance.
Indicates that coaching is unavailable for an alert because the driver is unknown or cannot be identified.
A symbol in the alert video indicating the start of a hard braking event.
A challenge made by a driver or manager if they think an alert is incorrect or unfair.
A classification for the type of dispute raised (e.g., invalid alert, extenuating circumstances).
A unique identifier assigned to each dispute made against an alert, allowing it to be tracked and reviewed separately.
Actions like running a red light that interfere with the smooth movement of vehicles.
Refers to when the vehicle travels over 45 meters after passing the red light before a second alert is generated.
A behavior where a driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s attention is diverted from the road, often due to phone use, eating, or other distractions, resulting in alerts.
A button used to save the video to a computer or device.
Dips on the alert video graph indicating periods of hard acceleration.
The sum of all driving minutes constitutes theâ€šÃ„Ã˜drive time
Assigning a specific driving session to a driver based on recorded data.
An individual who is driving the vehicle.
A score that shows how well a driver or the entire fleet is performing over time.
Driver Activity (App) tab focuses on driver-specific information. It displays the driver's unique ID, full name, and group information.
A method to capture and assign the drive time to the driver. There are various methods of Driver Assignment that can be used by the Fleets.
Steps involved in linking or reassigning drivers to specific drive times.
The ability of drivers to make independent decisions about their performance and safety, often through tools like self-coaching.
Comparing driver performance across Groups can help identify patterns and develop Coaching Sessions to improve driver skills, leading to enhanced safety and efficiency.
A detailed view in the system showing specific information about a driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s alerts, GreenZone score, and feedback provided during a coaching session.
Charts on the Driver Profile page that represent events generated by the driver in graphical format.
A page in the coaching sessions section that allows Safety Managers to view all feedback and disputes related to alerts issued for drivers, enabling efficient review and decision-making.
A central location for Safety Managers to see and review feedback or disputes about alerts.

Alert that detects when the driver is distracted for more than a few seconds. Driverâ€šÃ„Â¢i currently detects talking on phone, looking at phone, or looking down and considers them as driver distractions.
A tool to compare one driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s score with the average fleet score.
Feature that helps manage a large number of drivers by segregating them into groups.
A safety alert manually triggered by the driver.
Alerts generated when the driver or passenger presses a button on the device to report a hazardous situation on the road.
Driver Insight Report provides a comprehensive analysis of individual driver details for a selected duration.
Useful information derived from analyzing driver behavior to improve safety and performance.
The name of the driver associated with the alert.
Drivers are notified when a comment or alert is shared with them via the Driverâ€šÃ„Â¢i App. They can view the alert, watch the related video, acknowledge the feedback, or reply with comments.
A portal page where detailed information about individual drivers or the entire fleet can be accessed.
Repeated behaviors or trends in a driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s performance, like frequent speeding.
An assessment of a driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s behavior and safety metrics, including GreenZone score, alerts, and DriverStars.
A detailed screen showing information about a driver's driving performance and most frequent alerts.
A system that ranks drivers based on their performance, such as safety or efficiency.
A detailed report that provides insights into the performance and behavior of all drivers in a fleet.
The feedback or plan for improvement provided by a driver in response to coaching or alerts, typically shared through the system's comment section.
The ability to keep drivers employed and satisfied, reducing turnover by recognizing and rewarding their performance.
Driver Score is a numerical representation of a driver's overall performance, considering factors such as Alerts generated and DriverStars awarded.
An alert triggered by the driver pressing the alert button on the Driverâ€šÃ„Â¢i device.
A report that displays Driver Details and Alert Statistics for drivers.
A report that summarizes details about the drivers active at the time of generating the report and drivers who were deactivated during the previous week.

Driver Streaks are designed to recognize and reward consistent safe driving practices. They serve as a performance measurement tool that motivates drivers to continually exhibit safe behaviors on the road.
An application providing diagnostics to troubleshoot CAN connectivity issues by identifying missing or disconnected data points.
This section provides a graphical representation of GreenZone Score, Total Number of DriverStars, Total Number of Alerts generated for the selected duration.
The group responsible for reviewing feedback and ensuring alerts are accurate and useful.
A tab that tracks progress toward performance goals for drivers and fleets.

term: Drivers not part of any Group
notes: Lists active drivers in the fleet not assigned to any Group.

notes: A section in the Portal where Safety Managers view details about drivers in their fleet.
A screen that shows the performance and alerts of drivers in a fleet.
DriverStars are awarded to drivers in recognition of great driver performance and are intended to encourage drivers to practice safe driving behavior.
Positive driving events used to highlight good performance alongside areas needing improvement.

A type of DriverStar that is awarded when a driver completes 75Â¬â€ FullÂ¬â€ Stops in a row. The DriverStar Steak is issued 24 hours after the 75 stops are identified to allow sufficient time for Driver Assignment. A custom video is played congratulating the Driver on completing 75 full stops in a row.
Recognitions given to drivers for good driving behavior, intended to encourage safe driving.
Weather conditions at the time of a collision, like clear, fog, or rain.
A Driving Minute includes any time in which theâ€šÃ„Ã˜vehicleâ€šÃ„Ã˜speedâ€šÃ„Ã˜reaches 2 mph for at least one second.
A period of time when the vehicle is in motion and being driven.
A menu that allows you to select options such as specific time periods for filtering data.
Identifying when a driver appears sleepy or tired while driving.
A list where you can select the time range for the graph.
The specific time period chosen for analyzing driver alerts or performance data.
Alerts that are generated periodically if an issue persists (e.g., every minute or every 10 minutes).
Processing data closer to where it is generated (e.g., in the vehicle), instead of sending it to a centralized server.
Achieving goals quickly and with minimal waste of time or resources.
Being thrown out of the vehicle, usually due to lack of seatbelt usage or a violent crash.
The connection of an Electronic Logging Device (ELD) to the system, which provides driver assignment data for device status updates.
Cargo that is transported while being kept hot, such as asphalt.
An email sent to the driver containing a link to set their app password.
Alerts sent to your email address.
Notifications sent to customers to remind them of pending actions, such as returning a faulty device.
If the driver is not using the Driverâ€šÃ„Â¢i App, alerts can be shared via email with a time-limited link.
A group responsible for analyzing accident data and coordinating responses during emergencies.
A feature in the app that the driver taps when they finish their trip to mark the end of their driving session.
A warning for excessive shaking in a vehicleâ€šÃ„Ã´s engine, often in heavy vehicles.
A feature that disables some inward camera recordings but is overridden during Driver Initiated Alerts.
Permission for drivers to view specific incidents or videos related to their driving.
A page where you can view or download videos once they are processed and uploaded, associated with a specific event or alert.
A video recorded by the system for a driving event that did not create an alert.
A tab that breaks down the types and frequency of events (like alerts) across the fleet.
The video or other media content associated with an alert, showing the specific incident or behavior that triggered the alert.
A unique identifier assigned to each event or alert in the system, used to track and review alerts efficiently.
A summary of alerts and driver performance, presented in chart formats
A Pie Chart or Bubble Chart that displays the number of alerts graphically for individual drivers or all drivers to give an overview of the overall performance of the Fleet.
A video recording of a particular driving event, often showing the context of an alert or behavior, which can be played for review.
A graphical representation of Fleet performance that displays the number of alerts over time. The alert count is grouped by severity and type.
Highlights the aggregated real-time alerts based on the violation types and DriverStars. Events Panel is available on the Fleet Performance page in Dashboard.
A section in the app that shows a list of all events (such as alerts and driver performance indicators) recorded within a specific time frame.
A graphical representation of events (Alerts, Recognitions, Notifications) over a time period, used to analyze trends and patterns in fleet performance.
Recorded videos used to resolve disputes or incidents by showing proof of events.
Yawning three times in five minutes while driving, detected as a moderate sign of drowsiness.
Summaries of Fleet and Driver performance, including rankings, risks, and recommendations.
This section provides information about the overall demographics, such as Number of Vehicles, Distance, Total Traffic Lights, Total Stop Signs, Total Driving Time, and Total Traffic Time.
A detailed report summarizing fleet performance, driver rankings, alert profiles, and coaching recommendations, generated on a weekly or monthly basis.
Indicates whether a driver is exempt from the regulations that limit driving hours, typically for specific driver types or scenarios
A feature to download geofence data in CSV format for external use.
Additional cameras connected to the Driverâ€šÃ„Â¢i system, which can also be used for audio recordings.
How the eyes move or stay open, used to detect drowsiness, such as slow blinking or closed eyes.
Comments or disputes submitted by drivers or managers about the validity of an alert.
A section to provide input or evaluations regarding an alert.
The area visible in the camera view, showing detected vehicles, road signs, or traffic signals.
Choices that allow users to sort and display alerts by their risk level (e.g., severe, moderate).
A tool to sort and narrow down data, making it easier to focus on specific driver details.
A situation where there is a risk of fire.
Materials like oil and gas that can easily catch fire.
A group of vehicles associated with a Customer.
The permissions or rights granted to a user to access and manage specific fleets in the system.
A page in the Dashboard that displays the summarized view of administrative issues that require the manager's attention
Displays a summarized view of Device Health, Provisioning & Configurations, Vehicles, and Groups for operational or administrative oversight.
A feature that allows the user to compare selected Fleets and generate a report.
How well a group of vehicles and their drivers follow safety regulations.
A configured value of GreenZone Score to identify the drivers who are performing well. The value can be configured in the range of 0 to 1000. Default value is set at 850. See GreenZone Score.
Fleet Goal and Fleet Average provide context for comparing the individual driver's performance against both the Fleetâ€šÃ„Ã´s objectives and the average performance of other drivers in the Fleet.
A configuration that applies to all vehicles in a group managed by the same organization.
Individuals responsible for managing a fleet of vehicles and drivers, ensuring safety and performance.
Data and statistics that evaluate the overall safety and performance of a fleet of drivers.
The management and coordination of a group of vehicles, usually in a company or organization.
Notes or feedback added by users from the Fleet or Netradyne, which stop the automated device state transition once added.
Presents a high-level view of the overall efficiency and effectiveness of the fleet operations.
A tool used by Safety Managers to monitor and manage the safety metrics of a fleet, such as vehicles and drivers, providing insights for informed decision-making.
A summary of key performance metrics within a fleet management system
A pattern showing how the fleet's performance changes over time.
Initial report containing key data about a collision, used for claims and investigations.
An alert that is raised if the driver did not maintain a safe distance with the vehicle ahead.
Provides graphical representation of Average Following Distance distribution and the distribution of Following Distance Alert subtypes that were generated.
The visible area captured by the camera.
A feature that lets users review the video one frame at a time for precise analysis.
Describes how often the system raises alerts when obstructions occur repeatedly during a trip.
The most commonly occurring alerts, ranked in descending order to highlight critical safety issues.
Month
An alert triggered when a driver follows another vehicle too closely, not maintaining the recommended safe distance.
The complete video recorded for an event, including audio if available.
Watching an alert video from start to end without skipping any part.
A measure of acceleration relative to gravity, used to indicate the severity of a turn.

An upgraded alert that has been tested for its precision in Beta stage. Once a certain threshold is reached, the alert is upgraded and made available to all. It may start impacting the GreenZone Score.
The exact geographic position of the vehicle, including altitude, latitude, and longitude.
Geofence Activity Report offers a comprehensive view of vehicle activity within a designated virtual boundary, surrounding a specific geographical area.
Process of creating a perimeter or boundary for a certain geolocation per alert type so that any event generated in that geofence is suppressed.
The specific place where something is situated, described by coordinates or other location-based data.
Non-Translatable Words
A set of tools and software used to ensure that fleet operations comply with various transportation regulations.
G-force, or gravitational force, indicates the intensity of forces experienced by an object due to sudden changes in motion or direction.
A measure of the force exerted during a collision or sudden impact.
Default settings that are configured for all vehicles in the Fleet.
The component that receives signals from GPS satellites to determine the deviceâ€šÃ„Ã´s location, typically visible to the sky.
The period of time in which drivers must review and act on alerts. If this time expires without the driver completing the task, the alert is added to their Managed Coaching Session.
An icon used to expand an event to show more detailed information about the associated alert or DriverStar.
A line on the alert video graph that shows vehicle speed changes during an incident like hard braking.
The average of GreenZone Scores of all drivers in the Fleet, including unassigned drivers.
Refers to whether the alert affects the driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s GreenZone Score; in this case
Total percentage of drivers who have received notifications for a drop in score due to risky driving in the selected period. This can be accessed from the Fleet Performance tab on the Dashboard.
Total percentage of drivers who have been awarded a recognition for safe driving in the selected period. This can be accessed from the Fleet Performance tab on the Dashboard.
Score computed for the driver for a daily/weekly/monthly duration based on the Alerts/DriverStars generated by the driver.
Encourages drivers to meet or exceed fleet goals, promoting competition and improving overall fleet efficiency and safety.
A dashboard showing charts with data on fleet and driver performance to assess effectiveness.
Minimum value of GreenZone Score to identify drivers who are not performing well. The value can be configured in the range of 0 to 999. Default value is set at 600.
The organizational structure or group under which the vehicle or driver is categorized.
The Group Comparison report displays the Group Granularity tab with the Group Name, Group Hierarchy Lineage, and other information listed in the table below.
Information about groups of vehicles or drivers, categorized for efficient management and monitoring.
Displays issues related to group configurations in the Fleet Admin Dashboard.
Displays Groups without assigned drivers.
A sensing device that is used to measure orientation and angular velocity.

Non-Translatable Words
Non-Translatable Words
The state of the vehicle being switched ON or OFF.
The state of the vehicleâ€šÃ„Ã´s ignition (ON or OFF), which is used as a signal to determine if the vehicle is being driven.
Significant incidents or behaviors that negatively affect a driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s GreenZone Score.
Making changes to a product based on feedback to make it more intuitive, functional, and enjoyable for users.
Devices requiring further action by the fleet to resolve potential issues. Customers must check devices and provide requested information to the Netradyne Team.
Audible notifications provided within a vehicle to inform drivers of real-time updates, warnings, or instructions for improved safety and compliance in fleet management systems.
An event or occurrence, such as a vehicle stopping in a hazardous location.
Reviewing events around an alert to investigate and determine causes or responsibilities.
An option to add sound when sharing or downloading a recorded video.
Separate groups or collections of vehicles managed independently, typically used by large organizations or resellers who need to keep different operations isolated from each other.
Short sessions, lasting 5-10 minutes, focusing on delivering concise and effective coaching.
Visual representations of vehicle movement patterns, speed, and acceleration data, aiding in analyzing and optimizing fleet performance
Devices that measure motion and orientation to analyze driving behavior.
An icon that provides additional information about the group or category the driver belongs to.
A section displaying detailed information about the alert, like vehicle data, risk type, and location.
A setting that allows a driver to automatically use the same values or configurations as their parent fleet or group, such as carrier name or carrier number.
A system that allows drivers to engage with coaching content by providing feedback or comments, enhancing their involvement in the learning process.
Any unusual or noteworthy occurrences on the road reported by the driver.
A place where two or more roads meet or cross each other.
Displays information about alerts that the Tenant SafetyUser or Tenant Safety Manager has determined to be invalid after reviewing the feedback.
Mistakes or missing information in the driver details, which need to be corrected before saving or uploading.

The video footage from the camera facing inside the vehicle, capturing the driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s actions and behavior.
A video perspective showing the driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s actions during a driver-related alert.

Types of image formats for saving or printing the graph.
Month
Month
Understand how their performance compares to that of fellow drivers.
When a vehicle moves into a different lane, which can sometimes cause unsafe following distances.
A warning generated when a driver brakes hard after switching lanes to avoid a collision.
Staying in your lane and driving responsibly without unnecessary lane changes.
Data from the past three months.
A filter option to view driver details from the previous 30 days.
Data from the past six months.
The last time the device communicated with the system and its location at that time.
The geographic coordinate that specifies the north-south position of the geofence.
Generated when a vehicle makes a sharp left turn that exceeds the set threshold.
A rule or law that mandates certain actions, such as wearing a seatbelt while driving.
Labels above the chart that you can tap to filter specific details like your score or fleet average.
Legal responsibility, often related to accidents or violations, which alerts help reduce by preventing risks.
An optional field where a driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s official driving license number can be entered.
The registration number of a vehicle displayed on its license plate.
Not being able to see clearly due to blind spots or obstacles behind the vehicle.
Live streaming is a valuable tool for fleet managers, providing real-time video of their vehicles on the road.
Live Tracking feature allows fleet managers immediate access to the location and movements of their vehicles.
The risk of a heavy vehicle tipping over when carrying a load and turning abruptly.
Activities related to the process of loading or unloading cargo, which may cause low-impact events triggering alerts.
A warning when G-forces occur due to loading or unloading goods.
A setting that allows the app to access your phone's location information.
The process of entering credentials (username and password) to access an app or system.
The screen where you enter credentials to access an application.
The geographic coordinate that specifies the east-west position of the geofence.
A distraction caused when a driver holds and looks at a phone while driving.
A type of distraction where a driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s head is down for a significant amount of time, affecting road focus.
A situation where the driver feels lost or confused, often in unfamiliar or remote areas.
A notification triggered when the vehicle experiences a slight collision or force within specific G-Force thresholds (0.75G to 1.427G).
A setting that gives fewer alerts, ideal for experienced drivers.
An alert generated for events within the specified G-Force range, often for minor impacts or other forceful movements like speed bumps or sharp turns.
A component of certain devices that must also have a clear view of the sky for proper functioning.
A measure used to track overall behavior, like the average following distance, over a longer period.

A type of driver coaching that is driven by the Safety Manager. Managers can review the alerts for each driver and add them to a coaching session based on GreenZone Score, Risk Level (Moderate or Severe) and/or frequency for a future discussion with the driver.
A report that summarizes the coaching sessions for the selected duration.
Managers receive notifications when the driver replies to shared comments.
A traditional coaching method requiring direct intervention from safety managers to review and provide feedback.
Alert view that displays alerts based on alert locations, filtered by time or occurrence and alert types.
Month
An option to mark all notifications as read.
Switches that are provided in vehicles to preserve battery life and prevent theft or tampering. They work by cutting off the connection between battery and fuses that power the vehicle.
The highest speed the vehicle reached during the recorded event.
Month
A balanced alert setting suitable for mixed traffic conditions.
A button (usually in the top corner) that opens the appâ€šÃ„Ã´s menu.
Miles by Jurisdiction Report displays the Total Miles driven by a vehicle in an individual jurisdiction (state/province) for the indicated duration.
The lowest speed the vehicle reached during the recorded event.
Safely driven minutes as compared to a driver's total drive time.
Alerts that are configured to trigger when the driver exceeds the alert threshold by a small (moderate) margin.
Notifications for less critical but still significant safety issues that need monitoring.
A warning when reversing at more than 7 mph for over 3 seconds.
A warning for medium-level accidents, like hitting another vehicle at low speeds.
A collision event detected with a G-force between 1.43G to 3.00G.
A classification of alerts indicating a moderate level of risk associated with the driver's behavior.
Financial penalties imposed on drivers for breaking traffic rules, like running a red light.
A graph that shows performance data for each month.
A menu option to reject or modify alerts into DriverStars or Neutral Events.
Alerts that a driver triggers most often during a selected time period.
The events or behaviors that have the largest effect on a driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s performance, usually highlighted for corrective action or review.
An instrument, such as the GreenZone Score, used to encourage drivers to improve their performance by providing feedback and recognition based on their behavior.
A video combining multiple camera views into one for sharing.
A high-definition video with four different camera angles: Outward, Left, Right, and Inward, showing a full view of the alert event.
Indicates insufficient driving data to calculate the GreenZone Score.
A situation where a collision is narrowly avoided.
Normal driver actions that meet the established compliance thresholds for specific types of behavior.
A severe sign violation where the vehicle fails to stop at a stop sign and continues moving at a speed greater than 7 mph.
A traffic sign indicating that making a U-turn at that location is not allowed.
Refers to a small or minimal amount of battery consumption, even when the app is running in the background.
A method of addressing issues or improving performance without causing conflict, focusing on communication and support rather than punishment.
A place not officially marked or approved for parking vehicles.
Devices still installed in vehicles despite being non-functional. They must be uninstalled and returned to Netradyne for replacement.
Custom user-added information about the device, accessory, or vehicle to share with other users.
An alert sent to the driver via the Driverâ€šÃ„Â¢i App to inform them of a new weekly review session or pending tasks.
The proportion of drivers notified about risky driving behaviors during a selected period.
Feature that allows users to select how and when they want to be notified when various events occur within a time period.
Settings to customize how and when notifications are received.
Month
Indicates that the camera was obstructed for the specified duration.
Month
A short video captured and uploaded to the portal whenever the alert button is pressed.
A command that takes you to your phoneâ€šÃ„Ã´s settings to adjust permissions for the app.
Driving without any major incidents or risky behaviors.
Improving the way drivers operate vehicles, making them safer and more efficient.
Following rules and behaving in a way that maintains safety and structure on the road.
The version of the operating system (iOS, Android, etc.) running on the phone, which can impact the app's performance and battery consumptio

term: Other Vehicle Cut In Front Alert
notes: An alert triggered when another vehicle suddenly cuts into the driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s lane, causing the driver to brake hard.
A status indicating that a device is no longer covered by its warranty, meaning the manufacturer will not replace or repair it for free.
Put definition
The video footage from the camera facing outside the vehicle, capturing road conditions and surroundings.
A video perspective showing the road and surroundings during a driving-related alert.
Over Speeding Percentage (%) is the percentage of the total amount of time for which alert(s) were generated divided by total drive time.

Generated when the vehicle is speeding beyond the specified speed limits. The speed limit of the road can be fetched from multiple sources, such as third-party service providers, speed limit signs, and Netradyne speed limit database.
Helps optimize vehicle usage, reduce fuel consumption, and minimize idle time, which can lead to significant cost savings.
Watching only part of an alert video, not completing it.
An alert triggered by a passenger pressing the alert button on the Driverâ€šÃ„Â¢i device.
The movement of unsecured passengers in a vehicle due to sudden braking or high G-forces.
A vehicle that transports people, such as buses or taxicabs.
A secure code used by drivers to access the app, either set by themselves or provided by the manager.
The process of creating, storing, and resetting passwords to access secure systems.
Rules for creating strong passwords, such as length and character requirements.
Specific times when certain types of events or alerts occur more frequently.
Consequences for not following traffic laws, such as fines or losing a driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s license.
Indicates that the coaching session for the alert is still in progress and has not been completed yet.
Devices received by the Fleet from Netradyne that are yet to be installed in the vehicles.
A coaching session that has not yet been completed by the driver, marked as incomplete in the system.
A section on the Driver Disputes page showing disputes that are still being evaluated.
The process of reviewing a driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s driving record and improvement.
A signal sent by a device at regular intervals, indicating the device is still operational, but may not be receiving regular driving data.
A location where certain actions, like a U-turn, are allowed because it is safe and does not disrupt traffic.
Refers to a vehicle's use for personal, non-work-related travel, which may or may not be allowed depending on the driver's status.
Alerts that do not have the right precision and hence are not made customer visible.
Hazardous materials transported in quantities large enough to require warning labels or signs on the vehicle.
Vehicles with devices that responded in the last 30 days but were not associated with the vehicle at that time in the Portal.
An option to watch the video recorded during an event, showing different camera views.
A setting on the score chart to display the Projected Score as a dotted line for easy comparison with actual scores.
The part of the vehicle that was hit during the collision (e.g., front, back, left side).
A geofence defined by multiple connected latitude and longitude points forming a closed shape.
The minimum GreenZone Score required to avoid being rated as a poor performer.
A brief notification that appears on the screen to confirm an action or provide information, like confirming that the video request was successfully sent.
Safe or commendable driving actions identified by the Driverâ€šÃ„Â¢iÂ¬Ã† device.
Lists the count of DriverStars awarded to drivers.
See DriverStars.
The maximum allowed driving speed displayed on road signs.
A situation where a crash might occur if no corrective action is taken.
The possible or projected GreenZone Score that can be scored by drivers if they had avoided the alerts generated by them.
Unsafe driving conditions or habits that could lead to accidents or violations.
A list of features already specified in the system, from which users can select to report issues or suggest improvements.
A return label that is provided by the Driver.i team for sending back the faulty device, with no cost to the customer.
Predefined conditions used to display only relevant data when navigating through the dashboard.
A feature that lets users view video footage of the minute before or after an alert occurred.
A standard definition video from a single camera angle, relevant to the alert, such as from the front or back of the vehicle.
Options to save or print the chart in different image formats.
Conducting coaching in a confidential environment to respect the driver's privacy.
An icon shown on the app video indicating that Privacy Mode is active and no inward recording is happening.
Mode in which the inward video files (if an inward recording is enabled) will not be stored in the device. The video file cannot be retrieved.
Actions taken by drivers to prevent unsafe situations, like slowing down or adjusting their position to avoid accidents.
Steps taken in advance to prevent parking-related hazards in the future.
A location where multiple alerts or incidents frequently occur.
Projected Score indicates the score the driver could have obtained if the High Impact Alerts were not generated.
Setting up or enabling a feature in a system.
A section in the Fleet Admin Dashboard for managing and monitoring Driver.i devices to ensure optimal functionality and fleet health.
The closeness of one vehicle to another, affecting the following distance.
The distance from the center to the edge of a circular geofence.
Generated if the driver did not stop at the railroad crossing sign and kept driving at a speed greater than 7mph or rolled through at a slower speed.
A warning when the vehicle doesnâ€šÃ„Ã´t slow down or stop at railway crossings.
The position of a driver in comparison to others, often based on their performance, such as GreenZone Score and other factors.
The delay in response time when a driver is distracted, making it more likely to miss potential hazards.
The time it takes for a driver to respond to a situation, which slows down with distractions.
Allows for real-time decisions to improve overall driver score and driver ranking.
Immediate notifications sent as soon as a driving event happens, allowing for quick action or attention.
Instant feedback given to the driver during the trip, shown in the video annotations.
Data provided instantly to allow quick decisions or actions.
Accidents that occur when a vehicle following behind cannot stop in time and crashes into the vehicle ahead.
Mirrors inside the car used to see the area behind the vehicle.
The justification or explanation provided by the user for requesting a specific video.
The process of correcting driver information for a specific alert.
A situation where driving hours are attributed to a different driver, which does not affect previously created virtual coaching sessions.
A workplace environment that emphasizes acknowledging and rewarding positive actions.
The proportion of drivers recognized for safe driving behavior during a selected period. Recognition occurs when daily scores exceed a set threshold.
An initiative to reward high-performing drivers based on performance data from the GreenZone.
A feature that automatically assigns coaching sessions based on the driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s driving behavior, simplifying the coaching process.
Suggested training sessions for drivers based on their driving behavior to improve safety and performance.
An alert triggered when the light turns red after the vehicle has already entered the intersection.
A severe-risk situation where the Following Distance is 0.6 seconds or less for 10 seconds.
Swipe down to update the data on the screen.
The email linked to your account, used for communications like password reset links.
The email address linked to the user account for receiving notifications and reports.
An option to remove an incorrectly triggered or irrelevant alert so it doesnâ€šÃ„Ã´t affect driver or fleet metrics.
An action to dismiss an alert, convert it to neutral, or change it to a DriverStar.
A report that summarizes the alerts rejected by the Fleet for the selected duration.
The vehicle's speed compared to other vehicles on the road, used for internal tracking but does not affect app features.
Relative Speeding indicates the average relative speed of the vehicle with respect to other vehicles. This data is used for internal logging purposes and does not impact any of the Driveri features.
Utilizes the Driverâ€šÃ„Â¢i App to share performance information with drivers.
Negative results or outcomes from an action, such as penalties for violating traffic rules.
The procedure for sending a new device to replace the faulty one, including installation and vehicle-device association steps.
An option to inform the app team about errors or problems in the app.
Conditions or filters applied to generate specific driver reports.
Feature that allows the user to request a customized driver report based on specific criteria.
An option to retrieve the complete video footage of an incident.
The action of asking for a video to be made available for viewing, especially when it's marked as "Available on Request."
A section that displays the status of all requested driver reports, including pending and ready-to-download reports.
A recorded video requested for review of a driving incident.
Changing the planned path of a vehicle to avoid problem areas.
A feature to revert the Driver Score Chart to its original view.
A button to remove all changes and go back to the default filter settings.
The process of creating a new password when you forget the old one.
The action taken to mark an issue as resolved once it has been addressed.
The time taken to react to an incident or alert.
A report that depicts the total number of minutes of vehicle movement in restricted hours. It summarizes off-time vehicle movement.
A status indicating that the customer has confirmed they have returned the defective device.
A camera at the back of the vehicle that shows whatâ€šÃ„Ã´s behind on a screen inside the car.
Generated when a vehicle makes a sharp right turn that exceeds the set threshold.
A chart that categorizes alerts based on their cause, like third-party incidents or others.
The intensity of an alert, classified as either moderate or severe.
Lists the various alerts generated within the Fleet, classifying them based on their severity and potential impact on safety and operations.
Assessments of how likely a driver or fleet is to encounter safety incidents based on behavior.
The category of risk associated with the driving alert, such as speeding or harsh braking.
A form used to provide the address for the return label or replacement device shipment.
A notification about starting a Return Merchandise Authorization (RMA) process for a device.
Parking a vehicle on the side of the road, often due to lack of space at rest stops or truck areas.
A warning triggered when a vehicle is parked in a risky or non-designated spot on the roadside.
translation_nl: Waarschuwing voor Parkeren Langs de Weg

notes: Slowing down the vehicle but not stopping completely.
When a vehicle tips over onto its side or roof, often caused by sudden sharp turns at high speeds.
A warning for driving fast over uneven roads or potholes.
Roads that may cause uneven driving conditions, leading to alerts for low impact due to bumps or irregular surfaces.
Creating an efficient path for vehicles to travel.
A set of regulations regarding hours of service (H.O.S.) that must be followed by drivers, based on the selection in the system.
A streak achieved by maintaining safe speeds over time, currently not affecting the GreenZone score.
The space a driver creates between their vehicle and others to avoid accidents, especially when another vehicle is merging or parked on the shoulder.
Equipment like safety triangles or flares used to warn other drivers about a stationary vehicle.
Analyzing data from different Groups can reveal safety trends or issues, enabling Safety Managers to address them and improve the overall safety within the Fleet.
The person responsible for monitoring and improving driver safety and performance.

A DriverStar awarded by a Safety or Fleet Manager when they convert a hard-to-interpret alert (such as hard braking) into a positive acknowledgment, recognizing that the action was made to avoid danger.
An environment where safe driving habits are encouraged and rewarded.
Week
Visual representations of GreenZone Scores over time (daily, weekly, or monthly).
A graphical or numerical representation of a driver's performance over time, showing improvements or declines in key metrics.
A text box used to find specific geofences by name.
Generated when the driver does not wear the seat belt at the starting of the trip.
When a driver or passenger doesnâ€šÃ„Ã´t wear a seatbelt while the vehicle is in motion.
Time
Time
Any potential danger, such as robbery or suspicious activity, that risks the safety of the driver or vehicle.
A control to fast forward or rewind video playback.
A field allowing managers to pick specific drivers for whom automated coaching sessions will or wonâ€šÃ„Ã´t be created.
A feature that allows drivers to review and address alerts on their own, without requiring direct intervention from safety managers.
A feature to adjust how early or frequently collision alerts are given to drivers.
Acknowledgment given when a driver creates a safe distance by reducing speed.
The safe distance maintained between vehicles to prevent accidents.
The order in which things happen, useful for identifying patterns or trends over time.
A specific time period dedicated to coaching and discussing feedback with a driver.
A documented summary of the coaching session used to guide and review discussions.
A unique number assigned to each coaching session.
Drivers are notified via the Driverâ€šÃ„Â¢i app about the weekly review session, which they must complete within a week.
A part of the app where you can adjust permissions and preferences.
Alerts that are configured to trigger when the driver exceeds the alert threshold by a large (severe) margin.

term: Severe Alerts (Managed Coached and Virtual Coached)
notes: This KPI breaks down the total Severe Alerts into those that have been addressed through Managed Coaching and Virtual Coaching.
translation_nl: Ernstige waarschuwingen (Beheerde coaching en Virtuele coaching)

notes: A warning when reversing at more than 10 mph for over 3 seconds.
Severe Camera Obstruction Duration Report offers valuable insights into camera-related issues, helping Fleet Managers maintain the highest safety and operational standards.
A collision event detected with a G-force greater than 3.00G.
A classification of alerts indicating a high level of risk due to serious driving behavior issues.
The level of seriousness of a driver alert (e.g., mild, moderate, or severe).
Value that enables the system to decide if an alert is Severe or Moderate.
The geometric outline (like a circle or polygon) of the geofence area.
A feature to share alert videos as a link for others to view.
An option to share alert videos directly with drivers via their Driver-i app account.
A screen showing all recorded driving events (Neutral Events, Alerts, and DriverStars).
A process of tracking the return shipment of a faulty device and the replacement shipment.
An option to display only unread notifications.
A button to toggle visibility of the entered password on the login screen.
Mirrors on the outside of the car to see the sides and blind spots.
Ignoring traffic signs such as stop signs or yield signs.
Alerts generated when a driver violates traffic signs or signals, impacting safety
The process where the SIM card in the faulty device will no longer function 30 days after the RMA request is received.
A video with one camera view shared individually.
Being aware of what is happening around you while driving, which is reduced when distracted.
Losing control of the vehicle's movement, often due to sudden turns or slippery road conditions.
The option to avoid filling out the feedback survey. If skipped once, it prompts again after 24 hours.
An option to organize events in order of time, from earliest to latest or vice versa.
Devices that are with the customer but for which SIM is not activated.
An alert triggered when a vehicle passes over a speed bump too quickly without slowing down.
Raised sections of a road designed to slow down traffic, which can sometimes trigger low impact alerts.
The act of driving above the posted speed limit, which can trigger alerts indicating potential danger.
Driving above the speed limit specified by the fleet for a prolonged time.
Sudden upward or downward movements in the yellow trace graph indicating sharp left or right turns.
Driving faster than the posted speed limit in a specific location.

term: Start and End Dates of the Trip
notes: Helps monitor trip duration and identify any deviations from the planned schedule.
translation_nl: Begin- en einddatum van de reis

notes: A feature in the app that the driver taps when they begin a trip to mark the start of their driving session.
The state where the geofence is located.
The duration for which a vehicle remains stopped or parked in one place.
The outcome of a dispute review, which can be Accepted, Denied, Pending, or In Review.
Combining multiple camera views into a single, continuous video.
A section in the portal where stitched videos are stored and available for download or sharing.
Alerts triggered when a driver fails to stop at a stop sign or does not follow the proper procedure
Adhering to the rule of coming to a full stop at stop signs.
Successfully stopping at all stop signs over a period without violations.
A recognition given to drivers who stop at 75 stop signs consecutively without missing any.

term: Stop Sign Violations||STOP SIGN VIOLATIONS||STOP SIGN VIOLATION||Stop Sign Violation||Stop Sign-Violation
notes: When drivers fail to completely stop at a stop sign.
Helps ensure drivers adhere to designated parking areas and identify potential unauthorized stops or deviations from the planned route.
The specific address or location within the geofence.
The action of entering answers to survey questions and sending them for review.
The action of sending a request to retrieve a specific video.
A button used by managers to give feedback on an alert, deciding if itâ€šÃ„Ã´s valid or invalid.
The option to receive the report on a recurring basis (weekly or monthly) via email.
Feedback option to share ideas for improvements or new features related to alerts.

The team you can contact for help with special requirements or permissions for audio recording.
Stop specific notifications from being sent in designated areas.
Monitoring recorded footage to maintain safety and review incidents like accidents.
The appearance of the survey feedback on the screen after logging in, typically after 10 seconds.
A notification that encourages users to submit their feedback about the app.
A method to gather user opinions and experiences about the app, which helps to improve the app over time.
Suggested coaching sessions based on a driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s behavior and alert history.
Driving too closely behind another vehicle, reducing reaction time to sudden stops or changes.
A distraction caused when a driver holds a phone to their ear while driving.
A real-life instance, like a video, showing good driving behavior for learning purposes.
Specific updates made to a driver's details without affecting other records.
Specific training to help a driver improve areas of weakness and reach their potential score.
Focused training sessions to address specific issues with underperforming drivers.
A time-limited URL used to share videos with others.
Users who manage drivers, coach drivers, and generally have access to all safety-related data relating to the Driveri system.
Owners of the customer account who can perform all the actions that are allowed for a customer in IDMS.
A user with special permissions to manage advanced settings like enabling audio recording.
The trial period for a feature to identify and address any issues.
Alerts caused by actions of other people or vehicles, not the driver.
When another vehicle suddenly moves into the lane, creating an unsafe following situation.
The specific level of G-force or braking force that triggers an alert, usually indicating the seriousness of the action.
Weekly
The selected period (e.g., daily, weekly, or monthly) for which the driver report is generated.
The time period that must pass before a second violation can trigger a new alert (more than 5 seconds).
A menu to select a specific time range for viewing driver data (e.g., daily, weekly, or custom).
Sorting alerts by when they occurred to analyze events during specific time frames.
A temporary link that can only be used for a specific period.
Ensuring coaching is conducted within a week of the alert to maximize its impact.
The estimated time remaining before a collision occurs with the vehicle in front.
A control to switch between full-screen and default view for better viewing experience.
The â€šÃ„ÃºMinutes Analyzedâ€šÃ„Ã¹ column on the Drivers page denotes the total number of driving minutes for the driver.

term: Total Minutes Analyzed and Green Minutes%
notes: Total Minutes Analyzed and Green Minutes% offer insights into the proportion of time a driver spends driving within safe and efficient parameters.
translation_nl: Totaal aantal geanalyseerde minuten en Green Minutes%

notes: A high number of Severe Alerts may indicate poor driving habits or a lack of adherence to safety protocols.
Helps evaluate the efficiency of routes and identify any potential issues or delays that may impact overall Fleet performance.
The ability to monitor the progress of a device's return and replacement through the RMA process.
The movement of vehicles on the road, which can influence following distance.
Rules that drivers must follow on the road, such as safe reversing.
An alert triggered when a driver brakes hard to stop at a traffic light.
Lights at intersections or crossings used to control traffic flow and improve road safety.
Failing to stop at a red light or proceeding before it's safe.
Alerts triggered when a driver violates traffic light rules, such as running a red light or failing to stop.
Using recorded footage to help drivers learn better driving behaviors.
Feature that helps customers to transfer Active and Inactive devices between the Fleets based on their accessibility.
The process of spotting patterns or recurring behaviors in a specific area.
A line on a graph that shows changes in the driver's performance over time.
For following distance, this can indicate either total trends or the average distances kept.
A shorter version of the video, focusing on a specific part of the event, with optional audio.
The smallest circular turn a vehicle can make.
An additional security step requiring a code, apart from the password, for login.
Unassigned Drive Time Report provides information about the unassigned drive time for all vehicles within a Fleet.
A device status indicating that an issue is being examined manually. Devices in this state are not eligible for automatic updates.
To separate a grouped set of alerts into individual ones.
A placeholder for drive times where no driver is assigned.
Indicates that the camera was not obstructed during the selected duration.
Actions that other drivers or pedestrians donâ€šÃ„Ã´t expect, causing confusion or danger.
Reversing without proper visibility or control, which can cause accidents.
Actions by the driver that could lead to accidents or unsafe situations
When the gap between vehicles is too small to stop safely, often measured in seconds.
An option to stop sharing a previously shared alert video with a driver.
A button to save any changes made to notification settings.
A status indicating that the alert video is still being uploaded and is not yet available for viewing.
A symbol in the alert video that indicates the start of a hard turn.
Feedback option to indicate the alert was helpful or accurate.
Insights provided by users to help identify areas of improvement in a product. It plays a crucial role in enhancing user experience.
The different access levels or permissions assigned to users, such as Safety Managers, Drivers, and Auditors, defining what actions they can perform regarding disputes and feedback.
A notification triggered when a driver makes a 180-degree turn in a place where U-turns are prohibited.
Making an illegal or unsafe U-turn.
An alert confirmed to show correct information about unsafe driving behavior.
Displays information about alerts that the Tenant SafetyUser or Tenant Safety Manager has determined to be valid after reviewing the feedback.
A score that reflects a driverâ€šÃ„Ã´s performance and meets the criteria for generating reports.
The difference or change in performance over a period.
Helps identify and track individual vehicles and drivers.
The process of linking installed devices to specific vehicles in the Netradyne Portal for accurate tracking and data association.
A situation where the vehicle stops working, often requiring repair assistance.
The class to which the vehicle belongs. The vehicle class is determined based on vehicle weight.
Gross Vehicle Weight Rating in lbs/kgs as specified by the vehicle manufacturer.
The system used to start the vehicle, which triggers the inward camera to resume recording once the ignition is on and the vehicle reaches 5 mph or more.
A warning triggered when a driver brakes hard to avoid hitting a stopped vehicle ahead.
A configuration that applies only to a specific vehicle.
Feature to locate all the vehicles for a Fleet.
The highest G-force experienced by the vehicle during the collision.
When another vehicle moves from an adjacent lane into the same lane as the driver, requiring the driver to adjust speed or position to avoid collision.
An option to mark a vehicle as out of service until a specified time, helping to indicate that the vehicle is not in use.
The number assigned to the vehicle involved in the alert, usually a license plate number.
A vehicle stopped on the side of the road, requiring others to maintain safe distance.
This section provides a high-level summary of the Fleet, including details of Number of Vehicles, Distance, Total Traffic Lights, Total Stop Signs, Total Driving Time, and Total Traffic Time.
The process of linking the new device to the vehicleâ€šÃ„Ã´s system.
Represents information and statistics related to the fleet's vehicles, such as status or maintenance needs.

term: Vehicles not part of any Group
notes: Lists vehicles not assigned to any Group.
A menu icon with three dots, usually in the top-right corner, offering more options.
Features to watch alert videos and view the event location on a map.
A section that shows the status of the video related to an alert, indicating whether the video is ready, in progress, or unavailable.
A video of the driving event is ready to watch.
Time interval for which the videos are requested.
A unique identifier assigned to each video recorded by the system.

Indicates whether the video is ready to view, being uploaded, or available on request.

The option to open and save the report for offline use.
A clickable link to see more information about a specific coaching session.
View detailed information about an Alert or DriverStar, including its unique Event ID.
A unique code identifying a specific vehicle.
Vehicle Identification Number of the vehicle.
The amount of distance the vehicle travels after a violation before a second alert is generated.
The percentage of times a rule is broken out of all opportunities to follow it.

Type of coaching where the system reviews all alerts and DriverStars generated by each driver in the previous week and recommends a small subset of alerts that can be reviewed by the driver to understand areas they can improve further.
Alerts designed for remote coaching discussions.

Gain awareness about impactful driving behaviors affecting their score.
A small interactive feature in software, showing specific information like coaching sessions.
A format for representing geographic shapes like points, lines, and polygons in text.
Refers to the activity of moving a vehicle within a yard or parking area, which may be subject to specific regulations for drivers.
Opening the mouth wide to breathe in deeply, often a sign of being tired or sleepy.
